title: Portable cell lysis device for DNA extraction

description.text:
A 3D printable adapter to turn a Craftsman automatic hammer into a bead grinder for use with DNA extraction.
I call it the Smash-o-Tron 3000.

This thing is intended to replace the flange that holds down the retractable skirt on a Craftsman Nextec Cordless Hammerhead Auto Hammer. There are two parts; the base and the cap. The base should be screwed onto the body of the auto hammer with the screws that normally hold down the flange. Once the base is attached, a 3ml tube can be pushed into the pocket on the cap, and then locked against the striker plate of the auto hammer. When the trigger is pulled the striker plate will pound the living daylights out of the tube. There is a hole in the top of the cap into which a bolt can be threaded to adjust how far the tube depresses the striker plate, and thus how hard the tube is pounded. I based this design on the Xpedition Sample Processor from Zymo Research, and I use their lysis and stabilization buffer with zirconium beads. It also works very will with the Zymo DNA extraction kits, as well as DNA extraction kits from other companies (e.g., MoBio). Here is a video I did showing how to use the Zymo version : http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XfBTQl0q-Go As you can see in the video, screwing on the cap is a bit of a hassle, and the threads tend to get gunked up with stuff in the field. That's why I designed this version with a quarter turn twist-lock instead of full threads. Here is the Zymo version :
http://www.zymoresearch.com/devices-instruments/cell-disruptors/xpedition-sample-processor The lysis and stabilization buffer is here :
http://www.zymoresearch.com/buffers-solutions/stabilization-solutions/xpedition-lysis-stabilization-solution

comments.text: Toranado 3D design intent of using metal precision gears was to offer something better than the Greg Wade printed plastic gear extruders ... AND also to provide the community with affordable precision metal gear sets (you will not find a lower priced metal gear replacement of the same precision hobbed tooth quality) ... that is why Wes sourced these in high volume  (invested his money), to make these type of metal gears much more affordable to everyone ... the cost of such gears in the past has been very prohibitive to the DIY extruder builders, that is why wobbly crude printed gears have been the norm for so long. I would say it's a win-win open sourced arrangement, when people buy those precision metal gears, it continues the supply at an affordable price to everyone, and helps to justify the continued product support of Toranado 3D (Wes has been providing continual improvements, revisions, etc... I would say some of the best support of any DIY item on Thingiverse).
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text: You can see many another extruders made with a plastic gears, and it's works fine (for example Greggs wade extruder). I not recommend to print it from PLA, because it is not very strong, PET will be perfect for gears. Also it was designed for printed on 0.4mm nozzle diameter, and the idea that it is will be from plastic. I think that it will not live such long as aluminium, but depending from intense of print it will be works at least 3 month.

I had another extruder with plastic gears, it works really long time, and about six months  on small gear began to break off teeth. Really, who will have such problems knows what to do for lifelong of this gears.
comments.author: AcrimoniousMirth

comments.text: There were two reasons that I went with an all-metal gear solution:
comments.author: GarRemMash

comments.text:
Big thanks for such extended respond.
1) to create knowledge were used in metalworking and building involute tooth profile engagement, pair has been received by the full break-in teeth, so kept the gear ratio and load permanence.
2) in general, the engine does not operate at such temperatures, and it is necessary to reduce the current, and as well-chosen engine with good torque, such as is done in flashforge.
comments.author: Toranado3D

comments.text: Both of the NEMA-14 motors that I spec'd (and the one I recommend from Pololu) run hot enough at the rated voltage to reflow the plastic - meaning, the plastic softens, relaxes and warps.  Decreasing the voltage from the rated voltage - even a small amount, you will sacrifice significant amounts of motor torque.
comments.author: GarRemMash

comments.text: Now it printed from ABS, but I always print it with a Polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic, wich had temprature coridor in -60...+170 degrees, and have a good hardwearing qualities. After heat treatment it max temprature raises to 230 degrees. Really, problem with temprature impact to the plastic goes away. Two gears from USA with shipping to my country costs 20% of all printer, that's why I made this model. For me, aesthetics problem not such big as a price.

Kitchen towel ring.

EDIT: Added a small Test file to quickly print a piece of the bracket. Use that to test the fit on a cabinet. This towel ring fits a buyer-assembled Mainstays Kitchen Island Cart, but it should fit a lot of other flush-mount cabinet doors if there's adequate gap above the door. The bracket is a close fit on a door which is 0.7" (~17.5mm) thick, with an upper gap of 0.15" (~4mm) but might be adjusted with design software, such as Blender, or if the print software allows it XYZ scaliing might adjust the fit. Printing:
Almost nothing touches the build platform so there's no need for a raft. And little strength is required so minimum fill is ok. I got adequate print quality with 0.30mm layers and average speed.
60 minutes, 30grams ABS. Free the ring with a thin blade or tool.

description.text: In fact, this is a Z Endstop Trigger for the 3 Points Leveling for Makerbot Replicator... ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106474 ) Together with the thing mentioned above, it makes it very easy to switch between different thickness of glasses or not glass at all or this tape or the other... ...once the platform is level, just choose the build surface you'd like to use and adjust the endstop trigger accordinly, no need to level anything again! The OpenSCAD scripts I used are not available for download, the reason is that I'm using a new library for nuts'n'bolts which is still under development and has too much details to polish. Sorry for that. I suspect there's no gonna be much need for this thing, that's why I give it such a name. The Screw and the Nut are a nice thing to print and may have other uses.

I used ABS (plus acetone vapor bath), PLA should work also.  
For the screw and nut set I used a 60% infill, for the base the value was set to 25. The other settings are common: 1 extra shell, slightly low flowrate, active cooling (+ extrusion temp raised 3 degrees) and layer height... well I used 0.08mm however it should print fine with a value up to 0.2 or may be even more (?). Solid layers number should be set in such a way that they make a solid surface of, at least, 0.4 to 0.5 mm.  
Finally, the most important setting is the speed, too fast or too slow and the threads will not print nicely, they may still be usable but... In my case, 32 mm/s did the trick,values like of 28 or 35mm/s were showing some aesthetical issues.  
I used double side tape to install it in the stage.

description.text:
Every foamboard-type requires a test prior to cut the real thing on a lasercutter.

WHY?

The power you need depends on the paper-quality and paper-thickness. The Demo-Object uses foamboard of a store in Bern, Switzerland (http://www.lachenmeierfarben.ch/filialen/bern-aarbergergasse-56/), and requires the following:
Cut: 25 / 40 / 30 (speed, max power, corner power)
Semi-Cut: 80 / 40 / 30
Engrave: 100 / 30 / 20
Semi-Cut: Only the top paper-layer and the foam will be cutten. You need this to bend your object (see pictures)

Engrave: This is not done by the engrave-option of the lasercutter as it attends a closed figure. If you want to engrave lines and markings, use "cut" but with low power as mentioned above.

This technic is widly used by flitetest.com. So have a look there to lern how to construct and how to use the different cuts (A-fold, B-fold, C-fold). Here you find an easy example of a plane: http://flitetest.com/articles/ft-simple-storch-build

Be aware: The more power you need, the more foam will melt. And the space to fill with glue grows.

description.text: This is a fun little piece I did to explore some of the openscad functionality like for loops.  Kelly wanted a printed LED diffuser at the NYCR hackathon and she gave me plenty of room to improvise.  This is the result and I'm very happy with it.
Print with natural / white ABS or PLA for maximum effect.
Another grand entrance for our favorite castle playset.  1:18 scale.

The full staircase requires a 220mm build height.  Or, print the file in two sections using the "half files" which are approximately 110mm high each.  Print one copy of the platform file.  
I've also provided a "mini" file if you're looking for an awesome spiral staircase print for use without a playset - it's 110mm high and makes the best use of your build height.
No support should be required, but a fan probably is.  I recommend using one or two extra shells and at least 10% infill.  
Attach staircase to castle as indicated in image.  No alterations to castle should be necessary.

description.text:
This is the Cuisenare set by LeHof. For those that have never heard of Cuisenares, they are simply blocks of differing lengths that can be used to teach addition, subtraction, multiplication and division to children. You can also use these to teach fractions, create simple graphs and build structures.
These blocks are metric, add a 1, 2, and 5 block together in a line; you can count the blocks to get 1+2+5=8 or, use the other blocks to compare length to arrive at the same answer 8. Or use a centimeter ruler to measure the length which will also equal 8(cm).
Included in the files is a zip file with enough of each block laid out for a basic set (this will definately save you time). But when lil' Timmy decides to jam one up his nose, I have also provided the individual blocks so you can replace any "lost" ones.
The standard colours for each block are included in the file name, but these can be used just as well with all blocks being the same colour.

author: FlexyModern

description.text:
A working model of a planetary gear set. This model also allows the gear set to be exploded which gives a better view of the internals. This is accomplished by pulling the ring and sun apart. In its compressed or exploded form, the gear set is functional. The ratios are as follows:
Sun to Carrier: 3.3:1
Carrier to Ring: 0.70:1
Sun to Ring: -2.3:1 http://auto.howstuffworks.com/automatic-transmission3.htm

1)Print all pieces
2)Sand pieces smooth to ensure proper mating and free movement. Extra attention needs to be paid to sanding the Carrier's working surfaces.
3)Tap or thread the small holes in the top of the Carrier for the M3 screws.
4)Press the Carrier onto the shaft inside of the Ring. This press should require a little force in order to keep the Carrier from coming off the end but should telescope smoothly.
5)Add the 3 Planet gears and then the handle.
6)Secure with the M3 screws
7)Press the planet onto the Carrier shaft. Again, the beginning press fit should be tight but loosen up to telescope smoothly.

comments.text: Printed this on a Replicator 2 this week with the default medium quality settings. Had to sand the carrier down quite a bit to get the planets to fit on and the post in the center of the ring as well.
comments.author: Kabong

comments.text: Any reason the Ring gear doesn't match the Sun gear or Handle?Â  It's a slightly smaller diameter and the shape of the grip doesn't match up.
comments.author: LittleDangerous

comments.text: something wong slice the planet gears correct with slic3r.  The part looks okat, but the slice ends up with all kinds of weird stuff.
comments.author: zimmer62

comments.text: One of the best on Thingiverse. I printed on a Replicator, and the fit is very satisfying. I did spend a bit of time sanding. Even so, I broke the pin on the ring, it is a little weak at the base at 10% infill. Once I realized what little bits to sand down, the second one was much easier to install. I did print the second ring at 50% infill, but it is more important to sand down the locking tabs.

comments.text: Awesome :) the sun gear didn't turn out great - insufficient cooling made it look a little ugly, but works great :)

comments.text: FLIPPING awesome.  I finally get how it works.  Your model was perfect.  I had to sand just a few burs off to make everything work perfectly.  This is probably the best THING I've ever printed.

comments.text: Nice one! Printed at 100% all parts works great! Thanks Thing-0-fun!
comments.author: sirmakesalot

comments.text: I am having a blast printing this thing. My setup is an ultimaker at 0.1 mm layers and 100 mm/s feed. After scraping of some speed induced surface stings and blobs if fits like a dream straight off the bat! No sanding what so ever. The carrier to planet fix was a wounder to behold. I can't wait to print the last part, the Ring. As it is now it turns and telescopes nice and smooth. The only trouble so far was that the knobs on the Carrier was to big to be able to squeeze it into the Sun, so I carved off half a mm from them and presto  :-D

comments.text: All the knobs needed a bit of sanding/carving before allowing the inserts to pass that one crucial time. Please don't break your parts forcing them, remove half a mm and it still locks fine.

title: FX797 and F3 EVO mount for Eachine E010 Micro Quad (New LightWeight!)

description.text:
Combined FX797 FPV Camera and Tiny F3 EVO mount for Eachine E010 Micro Quad / Tiny Whoop

If you like my model, please consider using my affiliate links below to purchase recommended parts, or simply click here. Thank you! :-)

Features:

  • FX797 fits securely in top, with attachments for a small rubber band to hold it down.
  • Tiny F3 EVO board slots in snugly underneath, held securely by a clip over the front.
  • Easy access underneath the F3 EVO for Micro-JST motor plugs and soldering your wires.
  • Receiver taped underneath. May consider more secure mounting if needed, but seems OK for now.

Versions
"LightScrewlessV4_E010_F3_FPV_Mount.stl"
Lightweight version with tabs for rubber bands. Experimental version yet to be tested.

LightV3_E010_F3_FPV_Mount.stl - 1 gram lightweight version.

Version_3_E010_F3_FPV_Mount.stl - 2 gram extra heavy duty version.

Installation
Pull down the front of the frame and slide in the Tiny F3 EVO flight controller, push it right in, then release the lip and ensure the clips come over the top of the board and hold it securely in place. You may wish to add some thin double sided to be extra secure.

Printing
Note: I recommend printing with support and 100% fan. I used lines support with density of 30 (zigzag was too difficult to detach). You'll also need a good set of small needle nose pliers to remove all the support, assuming you have a very basic printed like mine (Prusa i3)

Part details:

  • Requires an Eachine E010 Micro Quad
  • Designed for installing an upgraded full acro Tiny F3 flight controller board
  • FPV camera/transmitter unit such as a FX797 which is tried and tested , or a cheaper Eachine TX-02 .
  • all your own transmitter, headset/fpv gear.

Alternatively, if you are a total newbie to all this I'd highly recommend you start with just the Eachine E010 and the FPV camera/transmitter mentioned, use all the included gear, and use a mount for the camera, such as this. Once you're flying that well, consider this upgrade.

More information on the Eachine E010 and similar mods can be found in this thread at rcgroups.

title: Simple hand spinner with miniature ball bearings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have seen a lot of hand spinners around the internet for some time, and it really peaked my interest! But most of them are using skateboard ball bearings, which are fairly big and clunky in my opinion, and won't necessarily be small enough to comfortable and discrete in your pocket. This one is small, slim, but still big enough to get to.

So this is just my... spin... on a hand spinner... sorry.

You will need a pack of minimum 3 miniature bearings: 695-2rs (5 x 13 x 4 mm)
The spinner body is 4 mm tall (Actually 3.5 mm) and the Buttons is 2 mm's each. So assembled together with bearings should give a max width of 9 mm.
It might not be a super fast or super long spinning spinner, but I don't really care, it gives my hands something to do.
You can also print a pair of extra buttons to place on the other bearings if you don't like the look of the bearings. You can print buttons in different colors to make your spinner your own!
The two other bearings at the ends are used as weights. And if you want the longest spin, you should choose the Large spinner (Shown in the middle) The one at the top was the first prototype

title: Malyan M180 Curtain Mount DIN A4 for ABS printing

description.text:
I am having a hard time printing ABS on my glas bed since it will shrink so fast and so significant that warping is a real problem, so I tried to keep as much hot air inside the frame and designed those curtain mounts to hand a sheet of DIN A4 paper on each side :)

It won't fit the print bed unless you rotate it to sit diagonally and to not exceed the limits with the skirt, I set it's distance to the object to 1mm.

I print in ABS at 220°C at a speed of 70mm/s and the bed at 105°C for the first layer (to speed up the heat up time) and then run it at max 120°C (it won't reach it but it will help with warping)

Edit: made a support thing so the piece of paper gets some support^^ (in the pics I am using failed prints and stuff for that)

title: Starship Fan Duct for Prusa RepRap

description.text: These are the voyages of the Starship Fan Duct. It's continuing mission: to explore strange new 3d models. To seek out new prints and cool them. To boldly go where no RepRap has gone before. Before designing this part, I had used simple angled bracket to hold my fan (no ducting) and found that the side of my prints which faced away from the fan would not cool as well as the sides which faced it(duh!). This design is an attempt to cool more evenly from all sides. The provided STL has only been used and tested on my own reprap with prusa2 x-carriage, and j-head hotend. I can't really guarantee it will fit anything else. However, the design is a fully parametric FreeCAD python script which can be tweaked to hopefully fit other configurations. EDIT: I've marked this as work in progress, due to issues I just realized with the duct melting/warping near the nozzle. It doesn't touch the nozzle, but it's close enough that it causes problems. I printed this in PLA. ABS would have probably been better, but I'm not sure if that would still melt when using printing more ABS. I'll have to do more testing, possible tweak the design more so that there is more space between the hotend nozzle/j-head and duct nozzle.

HEY... LISTEN!
Before you go wasting a bunch of filament, this is a solid model, and is designed to be printed with 0 infill, 0 solid layers, and only 1 perimeter. Print this at the thinnest layer height that you are comfortable with printing. Thinner layers will leave less gaps on the flatter parts of the rounded surfaces. I printed mine with a 0.5mm nozzle, at 0.1mm layer height. Some parts of the print are tricky: the middle section of the cones (doesn't matter since it will be cut out post-print), and the very top of the print(the end of the torus). I had holes on the end and simply patched this with tape. After printing, you will need to cut out the middle section of the cone shaped nozzle. I used a dremel at low speed with a small paper sanding disc to do this. Clean up the edges with hobby knife, sandpaper, or jeweller's file. To install, remove your extruder body from the x-carriage, so that the hotend can fit into the center of the duct hole. The fan should press fit into the duct, and the duct presses onto the carriage. One the duct is on the carriage, re-attach your extruder. Script Tweaking Instructions:
This script was created for FreeCAD, and requires the included EasyPart.py library, which simplifies the python API a bit. Use the "Tools -> Macros" menu to open the script for editing or execution. From this dialog, you can view or edit the "Macro Destination" which will need to be where you place both FanDuct.py and EasyPart.py You can load your carriage STL into FreeCAD and position the model to see how it will fit before printing. To export the shape, select it, and use "Meshes -> Create Mesh from Geometry...", then select the new mesh and use "Meshes -> Export mesh..." to save as STL.

Using the following options:
text = TIMOTHY

First off let me say that any donations for this design are greatly appreciated, thank you very much in advance!

This 3D model is a cover for the transcend 200 dash camera, this model of dash camera has a silver coat around the lens this 3D model is designed to eliminate that shine.

It is as simple as sliding on to the dash camera.

I made this because before I owned a 3D printer I covered up the silver so that the dashcam was less visibile to potential thieves. Originaly i used black electrical tape which left a horrible sticky residue and constantly peeled of during hot weather so this is a perfect solution!

The print settings that I used are as follows.

Layer height - 0.2 mm

comments.text: Since most .22 cal barrels have 1/2-28 threads (eg. .22LR, .223/5.56), I was thinking you could widen the space where the end of the barrel goes to 3/4" and put a standard thread protector in since that is the standard diameter of them. You could glue it or put some type of locking system in to hold it in place. comments.text:
Never mind.
[[[Potential printers take note:]]] The rules (in the US) also take into account if it can be used on a different weapon, whether it can slow down gases, whether it can accept foam, yada yada yada. Also, if it can be placed on a real firearm (i.e. projectile propelled by explosive) for a sound deadening effect, then it itself is considered a firearm (in addition to a suppressor), and you have to be approved to possess it. So, (if it functions) anyone that prints it is technically in possession of firearm, regardless of your intent (according to the ATF at least).

only a small cross with slots for a measuring tape to measure and align the bed center.

  • go to printer configuration
  • define the size of the printbed (x and y size)
    (be sure that the size is updated, printbed preview)
  • import the Center-Tool and print it
  • measure the x & y distances to the bed edges
  • "x printbed lengh" / 2 - "x distance to the edge" is the x-offset
  • "y printbed lengh" / 2 - "y distance to the edge" is the y-offset
  • insert the values in the printer configuration, printbed offset.
  • thats all, now you should be printing in the center...
  • scrap of the little tool and print cool stuff :)

    have fun...
    if you like it please FOLLOW me or/and give it a LIKE :) , thx

remixed_from.title: Mini Drill Press for Hobby Drill

title: Mini Drill Press arm mount with set screw and Dremel Flex Shaft holder

description.text:
A new arm mount and Dremel Flex Shaft holders for the Mini Drill Press by MarkBenson.
The nut that holds the arm mount on the original file was rotating when I moved the arm, so I made this one with a set screw instead of a nut.
Besides the arm mount, there are Dremel Flex Shaft holders that works fine, but are not recommended. They are hard to put on the Flex Shaft and may break on the process.

Print the arm mount and use it like the original, but remember to make a flat on the shaft first, so the set screw can hold the arm mount in place.
The Dremel Flex Shaft is not really recommended. It works, but it's hard to put it on the Flex Shaft and may break on the proccess.

title: rPI clip - Nexdock connector for Raspberry Pi

description.text:
This is a 2 part clip to mount a Raspberry Pi onto a nexdock laptop. One part is glued to the case holding the rPi, and the other part is glued to the back of the screen on the nexdock. You just slide the pi down and the springy clips lock it in place. Push the handles open and it comes off.

Make sure you don't put glue on the springy arms when connecting to your rPi case. Dry fit the parts together before gluing to verify that the orientation is correct, and that you don't need to sand down any rough edges.

I use this on a rPi3 with a Pimoroni coupe case and it works great.

title: Tevo Black Widow - Modular X Carriage

description.text:
Modular Carriage for TEVO Black Widow

Note : Do not hesitate to leave me a little tip if you like the design. That helps me to pay the filament I waste when I print prototypes.

Description

This is a modular carriage for the TEVO Black Widow. The motherplate is fixed directly on the CNC X-carriage. Then you can add daughter-plates depending on your setup.

Note for TitanExtruder daughter plate : I didn't find a good way to leave the tension bolt cleared. But as the daughter plate is easy removable, I manage a hole to access that tension bolt.

Note : This modular carriage is also compatible with my fanduct : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1953697

Offsets for Sensors

I've designed the sensor mounts so they've all got the same coordinates.

  • Plate for Tevo Tarantula hotend or E3Dv6 : X: -40 ; Y: +10
  • Plate for Titan+E3Dv6 direct extruder : X: -40 ; Y: +16
  • Plate for Dual E3Dv6 : X1: -40 ; X2 : -65 ; Y +10

Additional hardware

(under construction)

  • 3 flat head M5 screws (the ones delivered with the Black Widow
  • 3 M5 nylon-lock nuts
  • a bunch of M3 nuts
  • a bunch of M3 bolts

Revisions :

*2017-04-23 :

  • Corrected : Tarantula stock hotend plate.

*2017-04-18 :

  • Corrected : Titan Aero (hole for thumb screw). Dirty way to correct but I didn't want the extruder have too much hangover on the plate.
    *2017-04-14 :
  • Added Titan Aero
  • Added Support for LJx12 Sensor family
    • 2017-04-08 :
  • v1.9.1 Release for E3Dv6. It is now compatible with either genuine or clones.
  • v1.8 : Genuine Chimera + Cyclop plate added
  • v1.9 Release for Tarantula : stronger
    • 2017-03-05 : v1.8 Release
      • Dual E3Dv6
      • Laser Cutter mount
    • 2016-10-15 : v1.6 Release
      • Motherplate design
      • Daughter plates design
    • 2016-10-12 : First release
      • Abandonned

(small) Hole clearance is always a mess as it depends on many parameters : your extrusion settings, the filament retractation, your printer's tuning. I used to add.3mm clearance around each holes but it may not be sufficient for some people. For holes that need to tighten threads, I reduce the diameter by .15mm.
Anyway, you must use M3 bolts on the mount.

description.text:
This was suppose to be a Croatian egg lure. (Sorry Roman I tried.)

From what I understand a Croatain Egg is suppose to float with the hook out of the water and be great for weedy or lily pads areas. With the inverted hook floating out of the water it should skip right over most vegetation without getting snagged. Unfortunately the design is suited more for a buoyant type balsa wood rather than 3D printing. Even printed at only 10% infill and heavily weighted up front I could not get the hook to float out of the water and if I added more weight it would just sink.

It still makes a great topwater popper lure so I thought I'd still share it.

I'm still going to play with the design and shift the weights more forward and see what happens so this is a "Work In Progress."

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.10

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

I printed these with a .25 nozzle.

I used a 4/0 hook and extended the shank with stainless steel wire. The front cavity can hold up to 12 BB's (6 per side) for weight. (this picture was the prototype with only room for 3.) 3 BB's really wasn't enough and the lure floated completely vertical. (it should still work as a frog though.) 12 BB's worked pretty well and produces some good pop action on the twitch. 9 BB's with a conventional downward hook setup produced a good angle and added a little rattle to the lure.

description.text:
String "Climbing" Ball is based on the dual spool design of this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1825987. It doesn't really climb the string, it just appears to do so.

Consisting of 8 unique parts (10 total), and only requiring the purchase of embroidery floss, once assembled String Climbing Ball puts to use the "String Climbing Mechanism" and further illustrates how string climbing toys such as these, some over 100 years old, operate.

And as an added bonus, as shown in the photograph, the lower ring doubles as a display stand to keep your String "Climbing" Ball from rolling away when on display!

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0bZZ2xgOE84.

Designed using Sketchup Make 2016 and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 2 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the files "Hemisphere Top.stl" and "Hemisphere Bottom.stl", I used the brim feature of Cura, however, rafts should provide similar support.

Parts I Purchased:

1) Embroidery floss (super center, sewing shop, Amazon, etc). Sewing thread is too thin, and standard cotton string is too large and frays.

Printing:

Print 2 "Tower.stl" and "Ring.stl", then print 1 each of the remaining pieces.

Assembly:

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required. If the tight fitting components are too loose, add a small dot of cyanoacrylate to each side of the pin, allow to dry completely (I use accelerator to speed the process), then try the fit again. Repeat until tight.

Assemble as per "Assembly.stl". I perform the assembly task in the following order:

1) Press "Spool Center.stl" onto "Spool Large.stl".

2) Press "Spool Small.stl" onto "Spool Large.stl".

3) Press "Axle.stl" into "Spool Large.stl".

4) Cut two 24" lengths of embroidery floss, and tie a knot into one end of each piece.

5) Starting with the unknotted end, thread the embroidery floss into the small hole in "Spool Large.stl" starting from the flat side, then pull it all the way through until the knot sits inside the hole. Secure the knot in the hole using cyanoacrylate glue.

6) Repeat step 5 for "Spool Small.stl".

7) Wind the embroidery thread onto the spools in opposite directions. On the large spool, leave about 4" of embroidery thread unwound, the small spool about 10" of embroidery thread unwound.

8) Slide one axle into one of the "Tower.stl", then the other into the second "Tower.stl", then press the assembly into "Hemisphere Bottom.stl" making sure the short embroidery floss exits the hole in the bottom of "Hemisphere Bottom.stl".

9) Insert the embroidery floss from the small spool through the hole in "Hemisphere Top.stl", then slide the top down the floss, align it with the towers, then press onto "Hemisphere Bottom.stl".

10) Tie one "Ring.stl" to the embroidery thread from the large spool. I tied a double knot, secured the knot with cyanoacrylate glue, then trimmed away the excess. This ring is the "lower ring".

11) Tie the remaining "Ring.stl" to the thread from the small spool and secure and trim it as was done to the lower ring. This is the "upper ring".

12) Pick the entire assemble up by the rings, the upper ring on top. Pulling either ring will cause String Climbing Ball to climb the embroidery floss. Allowing the embroidery floss to go slack will allow gravity to return String Climbing Ball to the lower ring.

Hope you print one!

description.text:
James Stana and I designed this in Google Sketchup.

ORMaC is our 4 foot robotic mascot featured at Orlando Maker Faire 2015 and soon to be joined by his companion CaMRO at Maker Faire Orlando 2016. The project is designed to work without any soldering.

Join us in other projects like this at the Orlando Robotics and Makers Club: http://www.meetup.com/Orlando-Robotics/

An electrical circuit that powers a Light Emitting Diode (LED) is a lot like water being channeled over a water wheel.

The battery potential, or voltage, is represented by a tank of water high above a reservoir. The higher the tank the greater the water pressure, or voltage, and the larger the tank the longer the battery will last.

If you cut a large hole in the tank, all the water will rush out quickly. To slow the water and make it last longer, you might install a valve or run the water through a hose. A resistor acts like a valve or hose to keep the electrical current from flowing out too fast, or your light from going out too quickly.

The Light Emitting Diode (LED) is like a water wheel that turns the energy of the flowing water into motion, or in this case light. It will only work in one direction. If you put it in backwards no energy will flow and nothing happens.

The switch is like a dam or faucet valve, cutting off the flow of water and keeping the wheel from spinning, or LED from lighting.

Assembly Instructions Step 1: Identify the blue resistor and bend the leads into a shape of a U as shown
Step 2: Insert the resistor into the slot in the front of ORMaC until it is fully seated in the slot
Step 3: Bend each lead into the horizontal slots as shown while holding the resistor in the slot
Step 4: Identify the green LED. Look closely and determine which lead is longer
Step 5: With the longer lead on the bottom as shown, push the LED into the back side of ORMaC’s head. Bend the long LED lead as shown and the short lead into the large slot
Step 6: Insert the battery with the marked side as shown. If you then press the long lead against the folded resistor lead, the LED should light up
Step 7: Insert the slide switch into the back of ORMaC as shown
Step 8: After aligning the round boss of the back into the LED hole, snap the back of ORMaC onto the body
Step 9: Slide the switch toward the top of ORMaC to light up the LED
Step 10: Hang ORMaC from your Halloween costume. Make sure he is secure so he does not get lost!
Electrical Components Light Emitting Diode (LED) x 1 100 Ohm resistor x 1 cr2032 3v coin battery x 1

title: Raise3D N2 Extruder Cooler filament cover

description.text:
I had an issue with pure PLA filament getting jammed in my Raise3d n2 +. the company supports using polymaker filament and their own. this could be due to the blend they use. the problem with pure pla with this printer is that the Extruder body gets hot. this with the enclosed acrylic over that the filament if fed through leads to softening of the PLA and the extruder ends up eating away at the soft PLA when retraction get heavy in the model.

This model allows for a cooler environment for your filament and allows you to attach an extra fan onto your printer!

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

need to print this in petg or something will high temperature resistance and avoid filament that is pron to warping. PETG is my recommendation

in order to assemble the part to your printer use the standard bolts you use to secure your acrylic cover. only two can be used with this design. after those are attached i would test to see if your print has properly aligned with the channel by feeding some filament through and loading it.

next you will want to plug a fan in to the 12v constant on plug, you can see below in the photo(Thank you TobyCWood for this helpful photo) where you can do this. (I used a 10mm fan from my first prusa i3 kit) depending on what plug your fan has it will fit loose in the housing for port. you might have to tape or glue it into the port. I taped mine at first then glued it cause it kept coming out.

you can use 2 m3 x 20mm hex bolts to mount the fan on the print. it should not need much pressure to screw down. the wholes are just small enough for the bolts to dig in a bit.

description.text: An acrylic, reverse painted set of Settlers of Catan tiles.  The raster images have been replaced with public domain or CC licensed artwork that works well with the intaglio ink instead of being burned into wood like the original design.

With a 30cm x 30cm sheet of acrylic, etch at 100% power, 30% speed and cut 100% power, 6% speed.  Apply intaglio ink to the back side.  Clean the non-etched portions and run through the lithopress to soak up some of the excess ink, then allow to dry.
There should be a second layer of hexagons cut from solid white acrylic to provide a background for the etchings.  There needs to be a white background to make them visible.  I'll upload a second file once I have one designed.
Inks used were Speedball Black, Cyan, some random red, gold and a mix of the gold+cyan to make the green.

comments.text: This looks awesome! Could you upload a .CDR (x4)? I tried importing the .svg but the lines went crazy. Also you might want to consider filleting those corners, they're pretty sharp (I cut my hand a few times making test pieces from your previous version). Great work though!  :-D

description.text:
A printable connector for Black and Decker 18V battery packs. Can be used to easily tap one of these batteries as a power source for electronics projects. I designed this because I wanted a way to use the battery with a simple plug that left the battery unmodified, allowing it to still be used in B&D tools and charged using the manufacturer's battery charger.

I use the plug as a way to power either a low-cost buck or boost converter, allowing me to deliver a few amps at output voltages in a range from a few volts to more than 30 V. Examples: Buck and Boost

Pictures provided show the other end of the wire with PowerPole connectors attached to facilitate easy use on a workbench. PowerPoles are not configured using the standard for ham gear, but rather are stacked vertically to distinguish them from the standard orientation. This prevents the user from accidentally plugging into gear that is intended only for 12V/13.8V.

The OpenSCAD script is included in addition to the STL file.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

15-30%

Notes:

I printed the connector with the deep, narrow notch facing DOWN; it still prints just fine without supports. It's possible that the model may print better with the rectangular holes facing DOWN on the print bed. If you have better luck one way or the other, let me know in the comments section.

The connector was designed to be assembled using solid 12 AWG wire. This can easily be taken from a piece of 12/2 wire commonly used for house wiring. Strip all the insulation from two wires that are just slightly longer than the connector length. Do not bend the wires; try to keep them as straight as possible.

On each of the two wires, take a metal file (or sandpaper, or whatever you have) and file down the point of the wire on one end so that it is wedge shaped. The tip should look somewhat like a doorstop. The goal is not to sharpen the tip, but rather to remove one side of the cylindrical cross-section on the end of the wire to prevent the battery terminals from snagging on the end of the wire when inserted.

The wire will be inserted in the small holes at the back. Orient each wire so that the slope that you created on the end of the wire faces the inside of each rectangular cavity; this allows the battery terminal to easily slide past the tip of the wire. The connector is designed so that the wires fit relatively snugly, so you may need a pair of pliers to push in each wire until it reaches the end of the internal channel.

Test fit the connector on a battery to see if it slides on and off smoothly. If everything works out, the length of wire exposed in each opening will be pressed firmly against a battery terminal when plugged in, providing a solid connection and sufficient friction to prevent the connector from sliding off accidentally. I think that the approach works quite well.

If the connector fits on the battery, unplug it and solder a longer wire to each terminal wire sticking out the back of the connector. You'll notice in the pictures provided that I used a short piece of red/black zipwire (making sure to attach red to the + terminal and black to the - terminal) to make the connection. I also used heat shrink tubing to help insulate the wires and solder joints.

Disclaimer

Like any do-it-yourself project, the quality of the constructed item can vary widely depending on the skills of the builder. This item worked well for me, but it may not be suitable for your purposes; use at your own risk.

print_settings.Notes:: I use PETG as it's strong and flexible.  ABS would probably be fine too.  PLA is probably too brittle.

description.text:
I have some folding wooden garden chairs from B&Q which have an annoying habit of unfolding when you are carrying them or trying to prop up against something to store. They tend to open up and hit you in the shin.

This little clip/hook simply holds the chair together when folded. Use with 2x 1/2"x6 self tapping screws as shown in the pictures.

Will probably work with various folding wooden garden chairs.

description.text: I found some surplus empty ABS spool cartridges for Dimension 3D Printers.  The cartridges are nice because they have rubber seals to keep the moisture out.

I doubt this is of much immediate use to anyone, but the file might prove useful for other purposes.
The upper peg is a 14.7 x 14.8 mm square.  The lower peg is 20 mm x 20 mm, plus a thin perimeter lip 21 mm x 21mm.
The .AD_PRT file is an Alibre Design file of the work-in-progress (most recently used to make the version 5 stl).  
Alibre is a lower-cost alternative to SolidWorks.  (I'm sorry -- I don't do OpenSCAD yet.)  
-- history of .STL files --
holder tower 5 - I changed the elevation of the X-direction bridge from the Y-direction bridge so that there would be less droop.
holder tower 4 - I hollowed out the design to use far less plastic.  There was a lot of drooped bridges at the top because the X-direction bridges and Y-direction bridges were starting at the same elevation.
holder tower 3 - The walls were too thin to be of any use.  
holder tower 2 - The lower peg dimension was enlarged to fit the hole on the ToM
holder tower - original attempt was more of a solid "block" design -- even though I ran it at 15% infill, it still used far too much plastic; also, the lower peg was sized too small to snug up against the ToM holes.

title: DJI Phantom iPad Mini Visor and Mount for Otterbox/LifeProof

description.text:
This is a custom visor/clamp assembly to work with a iPad mini (1, 2 and 3. Not sure it it will work with a 4) in a LifeProof or Otterbox case (Visor base included for both cases). The clamp assembly uses the stock hardware of the remote.

It will require a little sanding in the visor base channels to smooth out print lines and make visors slide in and out easily.

I also remixed the clamps from eburgess4 located at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1738401/#files to be stronger, and adjusted the angle on them to fit the tablet with the visor base. Can't seem to link the remix as the only way I can pull up his work is through Google. But kudos to eburgess4 for the assist! These clamps can be used instead of the replacement tablet mount, for those who want to use the existing DJI setup. The clamps will need some sanding to smooth print lines and allow them to slide on and off more easily.

assembly is simple. this is a mount designed to get the shaft pretty close to where a normal sized servo would sit on this kit, so i kinda made it only work one way (sorry).

feed servo wire through hole in center, align servo so wire passes through square notch while pushing the servo down into place. it should be tight. there are places for small zipties on both ends or a screw on one end (opposite square notch for wires).
because the base fits in the standard servo hole, you could get away with ziptie-ing the mount to the frame, or matching 5mm holes are provided for bolts.

This is a customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1407527

These files are configured to fit non-sleeved cards from the Star Realms series (including Colony Wars). Since the customizer can't output a multi-file Thing, I have gathered all the different iterations I have made into this one Thing.

The Base Game +_ Expac files are meant for holding expansions with trade row cards only (Currently Heroes, Events, Bases and Battleships, and Fleets and Fortresses). Other expansions are kept separate during gameplay and thus have standalone tray files.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed these with ABS at 25% infill with 2 shells as during testing they seemed to be strong enough to hold up to holding up my bot... Rafts are not required unless you print with them but supports are required.

description.text:
After a month of printing and tweaking bits here and there its time to get this bot level.
I never noticed just how much out of level my bench actually was until I got these adjustable feet designed, printed and fitted. I used (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104796) as inspiration for a set of adjustable feet that fit the strange bottom corners of my ctc replicator dual

Due to the strange and quirky design of the case or just the cheap production not a single corner is the same, Front left and Rear right should be the same as should front right and rear left but on my bot they are not. I could have made all 4 corners different to match the case but for the sake of 1mm difference and the hours of design work it was just as easy to make one front / rear set and live with it.

Printer:

CTC Rep dual Sailfished

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

25-50

Notes:

I printed these with ABS at 25% infill with 2 shells as during testing they seemed to be strong enough to hold up to holding up my bot... Rafts are not required unless you print with them but supports are required.

I used 4 x M6 45mm nuts and bolts from local hardware store.

Either tap the holes with an m6x1mm pitch tap (or what match your bolts) or put the bolt through the round foot and then tighten the nut down and use the assembled part to thread through the case part of the foot. This way it will be very tight and will require a fair bit of pressure to turn then round but it also means they will not adjust on there own as you use the machine. If you tap the holes then you can use the nut to tighten up against the case part of the foot to lock them in place that way.

I part tapped the hole 3/4 of the way through then screwed the bottom part in and used it to cut the last bit of the thread.

Once fitted to the case and your happy with them you can screw them to the housing with 2.5 x 5mm screws (or whatever you can find or have) so they do not come off if you have to move your bot. They are a snug tight fit on my bot so have not screwed them in and if you ever need to get inside to the mainboard area where the electronics are located you would need to remove the screws before you remove the adjustable feet then you can remove the bottom cover.

The Hammer has 7 solid layers on the top and bottom and 4 perimeters, so it's really durable. For the handle the same infill, i. e. 80%. For all other print parameters I set completely standard settings and there was not a problem.
For the hammer only a gentle sandpaper is needed and for the finish any common metal polishing paste. The shaft was sanding with a fine sandpaper.

title: 50mm print fan / blower guard for Prusa i3

description.text:
Now on v2. New for version 2:

  • in some cases the original bolts weren't long enough with the guard added. The thickness under the bolt has been reduced
  • bottom edge has straight cutout so that the guard doesn't touch the duct for the print fan
  • bolt heads sit flush for a cleaner look
  • the surface in the STL is solid - can hack the slicer to make the mesh. This gives faster prints, uses less material, and better airflow since the mesh lines are all a single line of material.

To print, in your slicer set top and bottom layers to zero, and use a suitable infill such as honeycomb. Increase the number of perimeters until the guard has a suitably thick edge.

ABS gcode suitable for a Prusa i3mk2 is also included with the proper settings for a honeycomb grille.

Guard for the blower on the front of the extruder of an i3 mk2. Could also cover any 50mm blower (the i3 mk2 is a 5015)

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

0.1mm layer height
no top or bottom surface.
honeycomb infill
10 perimeters
about 20% infill works well

title: Scalable CoreXY V2 (HICTOP Prusa i3 hardware Converted to CoreXY)

description.text:
This is my second version of Scalable CoreXY. The V1 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1587260) was vary large, and version 2 is just big enough for the HICTOP bed (220x270mm x 200). I have used the same motors, power supply and control board from the HICTOP.
I have had already upgraded my hotend to E3D V6, and also the lead screws, so those are the components I have used.

With this version I have also used the same smooth rods and linear bearings. I found that using 3D printed linear bearings can reduce the weight significantly, therefore all the bearings are printed in semi-translucent PLA and I applied some grease to them before putting them on the smooth-rods. So far they seem to be working really well.

Bearings are HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829916

I tried using Marlin 1.1 RC7 (latest to date) and I had constant buffer issues (the printer keeps chocking in the middle of the print). Tried using the 1.1 RC3 and 5 and buffer issues are not there. Since I'm still perfecting and testing the design I gave up on Marlin and currently have the same Repetier Firmware that I used on my V1 printer where I only changed the sizes to match the smaller V2 printer.

The carriage is a single hotend, however I am planning to test out having two extruders feeding the same hotend later on. I tested that on the Prusa i3 before I took it apart and found out it's only viable for very large prints since there are some contamination between the two filaments, however I really liked the fact that leveling the printer is much easier and the power consumption is less and oozing issues are basically gone. I am planning to give it another chance to see if it can be improves later on.

Carriage can be found HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1829930
Extruder can be found HERE: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1859692

I explored different designs for the bed movement, such as having 4 smooth rods. However in practice it did not make any difference at all. It only made the bed heavier and harder to move. It also creates the option of using two (2) leadscrews, however one of my big problems with the Prusa i3 was having to level the axis once in a while because the two leadscrews and motors are not always in sync.

For the bed movement, if you are planning to use the same threaded rods that came with HICTOP you can use the following.

Threaded rod Nut Holder for bed carriage: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1859730

I have been busy with work and life in general so have not been updating things regularly here.
I have uploaded all my source files for anyone interested to make/edit this:

  • CoreXY_V2.0_Cleaned.2.rsdoc is the complete drawing of all parts.
  • Repetier-Firmware-1.0.0dev_2016-10-31.zip is the current firmware that I'm running on the printer.

This has been quite successful and is printing well. There are a few kinks here and there that I'm working out, and adding and experimenting some features:

  • I'm considering ways to place the filament rolls and feeder on the top or somehow inside the printer, but I have not decided yet. we will see about that :D However I have been seeing some wired under-extrusions that turned out to be due to the filament roll holder (or rather lack of one, it's just a piece of 2020 sticking out the back at the moment) so that's something I have to fix soon.
  • I am testing a counter weight system for the bed to make the bed seem lighter/weightless to the motor, so it may be able to move faster or improve accuracy.
  • The next project would be to try and enclose the printer body and optimize the footprint as a desktop printer.

The design
My goal is to be able to make adjustments to my 3D printer without any tools being needed. That's why I designed this magnetic X carriage to be able to quickly change between different hotends. It has a total of 10 magnets which holds the quick plate to the X-carriage.

As always I'd love to get some feedback so please comment if you have time!

UPDATE: MGN12 carriage added!

This design was inspired by Thingirobs Modular X car (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795) so the credit for the original design goes to him.

ATTENTION
This part can be hard to print, especially the X-carriage. To help with adhesion use hair spray!
This design has very low tolerances, therefore you will need to file:

  • The underside of the holder
  • The side notches of the holder
  • The front notch of the holder
  • The holes are very tight and might need a bit of drilling

File until the parts go into each other without a problem.

I'm working on an Instructional video! In the mean time, ask questions if you get any problems.

WHAT YOU NEED
All the parts from the old carriage
10x 5x3 Neodymium magnets (https://goo.gl/XW8Cm5)
2x M4x20
M4 nuts (optional)
Washers (optional)
JST connectors (optional)
XT30 connector (optional)

FAQ
Q. Are the magnets strong enough to hold the hotend?
A. Yes! there are 10 of them! Combined they create around 6kg (12lbs) of pulling force.

Q. What about vibrations and movement? Will it create artifacts on the prints?
A. No! As previously stated there are 10 magnets and 3 notches to keep the parts in place. The vibrations and the movement won't affect the quality of your prints.

Q. Will it hold a fan duct with fans?
A. Yes! It will!

Q. Do I have to glue the magnets in?
A. No!

Q. You made the holes too small!
A. No, your printer did :D Use a drill bit and drill the holes by hand. Makes sure not to remove too much plastic

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 or better

Infill:

100

comments.author: Banholm

comments.text: Look at the model of the holder. You can see three notches. Two on the sides and one in the front. Those notches hold the part so it doesn't move in any direction until I pull the hotend out. I made it with no tolerance so once you print it you have to file down those notches until they fit in place. It all depends on how well you do it. If you file too much the part will move. But even if it does move when you pull on it, it doesn't affect the print. The model in the video is a prototype that doesn't have the front notch and it was poorly filed. but the pictures of the prints I sent you are from that carriage.
